original_title: Sri Lanka inflation down to 25.2-pct in May 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s inflation in the 12-months to May 2023 has eased to 25.2 percent from 35.3 percent a month earlier according to a revised Colombo Consumer Price Index calculated by the state statistics office.
During the month of May the CCPI Index was unchanged at 192.3 points.
Sri Lanka’s central bank is running deflationary policy and has run balance of payments surpluses from around September 2022.

The exchange rate was allowed to appreciate from around March, further helping bring down the price of traded goods.  The rupee has fallen to around 295 rupees from 360 to the US dollar at the beginning of the year.
From September 2022, the CCPI Index had grown only 1.5 percent.
However, it may take more than a year for the price structure of the country, including rents, wages and other services to fully adjust to the currency collapse in March 2022.
Sri Lanka’s inflation soared in 2022 after two years of money printing and a currency collapse, but policy was tightened from April 2022.
Moderating 12-month inflation is called disinflation. But food prices have fallen absolutely by 5.7 percent since September.
Sri Lanka expects inflation to come down to single digit levels by year end, helping bring rates down, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe has said.
An appreciation of the currency reduces the price of traded goods and may have a knock on positive effect on overall prices. (Colombo/May31/2023)
